title.narrative: Response against the epidemic fever, RV

description.narrative:
preventive and curative response against the epidemic fever, Rift Valley Tchintabaraden in the region of Tahoua
The department Tchintabaraden in the Tahoua region is experiencing a surge in the number of human cases of fever, Rift Valley, with already81 cases since early August and 26 deaths. For animals, the date of the mission of investigation services Health and Livestock, 39 cases in cattle and 117 cases for sheep / goats were reported on the sites visited. The first cases were formally reassembled the health teams in week 31 of 2016. The department is officially declared epidemic since 20 September 2016. A significant increase in the number of reported cases was noted. Two exploratory missions conducted by the departments in charge of public health and livestock (national and regional) have confirmed the presence of cases of hemorrhagic fever and the results of laboratory analyzes at the Pasteur Institute of Dakar confirmed fever Rift valley. Since the onset of symptoms in patients beginning inAugust, ALIMA in collaboration with the district health Tchintabaraden have supported patients who presented in health structures, covered by ALIMA. An isolation center wasimmediately set up at the district hospital Tchintabaraden by ALIMA. Rift valleyfever causes different symptoms in humans such as fever, headache, diarrhea, vomiting, hemorrhagic syndrome, jaundice and dyspnea. In diseased animals, the most common signs are fever, difficulty breathing, hyper salivation, bleeding from the nose, eyesand anus. Added to this abortions in sheep and goats. Regarding cattle, there was a high calf mortality. In addition, the milk of some animals aborted is streaked with blood. There is no vaccinefor humans, and the treatment is symptomatic. The diseaseoccurred in Kenya in the Rift Valley in 1931, and there have been recent outbreaks in sub-Saharan Africa (Mauritania, Senegal) and the Middle East (Yemen and Saudi Arabia) since. The Niger has never had a fever epidemic of Rift Valley. However, cases have been reported in 1992 and 2013 in the Tillabery region.

participating-org.narrative: ALIMA has been working in Niger since 2009 to deal with severe acute malnutrition and to reduce the mortality of children under 5 years of age. ALIMA began working in northern Niger in 2015 (Tahoua region, Tchintabaraden health district) with a project"Support for the medical care of nomadic and geographically dispersed populations in the Sahelian region, North Niger and the North Mali ", in consortium with doctor of the World Belgium and financed by the Delegation of the European Union. ALIMA is implementing this project in the Tahoua region, focusing on reproductive health and the care of children aged 0 to 5 years in the health system. A mobile health component to adapt to the nomadic lifestyle and a surgery strategy are also in place.
